unnormalised: Okay, so you're probably thinking about getting that next certification, right? Or maybe you're just starting out and trying to figure out what qualifications you need. Well, let's talk about it. In India, education and those fancy certificates are a HUGE deal. Employers really look at them. And honestly, sometimes it feels like you need a PhD. just to get an entry-level job!
normalised: Okay, so you're probably thinking about getting that next certification, right? Or maybe you're just starting out and trying to figure out what qualifications you need. Well, let's talk about it. In India, education and those fancy certificates are a huge deal. Employers really look at them. And honestly, sometimes it feels like you need a P-H-D just to get an entry-level job!

unnormalised: First off, you have your basic degrees, B.A., B.Sc., B.Com. etc. Many just write it as BA, BSc, or BCom. Then, if you are going for engineering, it is B.Tech or BE. After that, you have your master's degrees – M.A., M.Sc., M.Com. or MBA. These are essential if you want to climb the corporate ladder. And don't forget the ever-popular MCA (Master of Computer Applications) for the techies.
normalised: First off, you have your basic degrees, B-A, B-S-C, B-Com etcetera. Many just write it as B-A, B-S-C, or B-Com. Then, if you are going for engineering, it is B-Tech or B-E. After that, you have your master's degrees – M-A, M-S-C, M-Com or M-B-A. These are essential if you want to climb the corporate ladder. And don't forget the ever-popular M-C-A (Master of Computer Applications) for the techies.

unnormalised: Then come the professional certifications. Think CA (Chartered Accountant), which so many commerce grads are after. Or maybe you are looking at AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner or PMP (Project Management Professional). These really boost your resume and show you have specific skills. And in some industries, like IT, they are practically mandatory.
normalised: Then come the professional certifications. Think C-A (Chartered Accountant), which so many commerce grads are after. Or maybe you are looking at A-W-S Certified Cloud Practitioner or P-M-P (Project Management Professional). These really boost your resume and show you have specific skills. And in some industries, like I-T, they are practically mandatory.

unnormalised: Academic achievements are also considered titles in many ways. If you topped your class and secured the 1st Rank, you can flaunt that as a title. If you got a gold medal from your college, that can be added to the resume as well.
normalised: Academic achievements are also considered titles in many ways. If you topped your class and secured the first Rank, you can flaunt that as a title. If you got a gold medal from your college, that can be added to the resume as well.

unnormalised: Now, when you list these things, be consistent. Always put the institution first, then the degree and year of passing like - IIT Delhi, B.Tech (Computer Science), 2020. Don't mix up formats. It looks messy. Also, if you've cleared any competitive exams like the GATE exam with a good score, mention the percentile. Something like – GATE Score: 99.5 percentile.
normalised: Now, when you list these things, be consistent. Always put the institution first, then the degree and year of passing like - I-I-T Delhi, B-Tech (Computer Science), two thousand and twenty. Don't mix up formats. It looks messy. Also, if you've cleared any competitive exams like the G-A-T-E exam with a good score, mention the percentile. Something like – G-A-T-E Score: ninety nine point five percentile.

unnormalised: And remember, while these certificates and qualifications are important, don't let them be the ONLY thing you focus on. Real-world experience matters just as much, maybe even more! Try to balance both – get that degree, but also get some internships or freelance work under your belt. You need a mix of knowledge and skills.
normalised: And remember, while these certificates and qualifications are important, don't let them be the only thing you focus on. Real-world experience matters just as much, maybe even more! Try to balance both – get that degree, but also get some internships or freelance work under your belt. You need a mix of knowledge and skills.

unnormalised: So, good luck with your studies and your certification journeys! Remember to keep learning and upskilling yourself. This is India, after all, and the competition is fierce. But with the right qualifications and the right attitude, you can achieve anything! Jai Hind!
normalised: So, good luck with your studies and your certification journeys! Remember to keep learning and upskilling yourself. This is India, after all, and the competition is fierce. But with the right qualifications and the right attitude, you can achieve anything! Jai Hind!
